JOHNS HOPKINS UNIVERSITY
VOL. XVIII, NO. 19.

BALTIMORE, MD., MARCH 9, 1914.

PRICE, FIVE CENTS

HOOPER SIGNS WITH THE "FEDS"

HAZING IS PUT ON A NEW BASIS

INTERCLASS CONTEST ON FRIDAY HOPKINS TRACK MEN VICTORIOUS

Baseball Coach Signs One-Year Contract
With Pittsburgh —Will Not Interfere With His Work Here.

Faculty Revises Rules and Vests Student
Council With Regulating Power.
Novel Contest Planned.

Juniors and Seniors to Debate on Monroe
Doctrine—Sophomore Oratorical
Contest at Same Time.

Win Meet and Handsome Cup in Annual
Georgetown Games—Connolly
Is S. A.A. Champion.

"Eddie" Hooper, coach of the
'Varsity baseball team, has signed
a one-year contract with the Pittsburgh team of the Federal League.
The position, however, will interfere in no manner with his connection with Hopkins, for he will
not join the Smoky City team until
he has whipped the Hopkins nine
into shape and piloted it through
its schedule.
Coach Hooper was formerly a
member of the York (Tri-State)
team and last season was one of
its most sensational fielders. He
was a player on the Baltimore
Orioles before going to York. While
on the local team, however, he had
continuous trouble with his arm,
which interfered with batting, and
he was forced to retire to a league
where he would not be required
to play so strenuously.
Nearly a month ago friends of
Coach Hooper learned that the
"Feds" were flirting with him.
First came the rumor that the
Indianapolis team wanted him, but
later it developed that Pittsburgh
had taken a fancy to his excellent
record as a fielder for York. The
offer came to Coach Hooper, but
he said nothing about it to his Hopkins charges. He considered the
•
`jump"
for some time, and finally
decided to sign the Pittsburgh contract.
It will not be necessary, however,
for him to leave the Hopkins team
until its season is closed. Even
while a member of the York team
he went through nearly the whole
Hopkins season before reporting
to his own team, and as the Teds"
will not organize until late in the
year, he will possibly be able to be
with the 'Varsity the entire season
this year before leaving.
The contract signed with Pittsburgh calls for one year's service,
and the salary is a great deal more
attractive than that of York. Coach
Hooper will be playing in company
with some of the big stars of the
Americah national game, and if current reports are to be believed, he
will face the pitching of "Christy"
Mathewson, the Giant, who is said
- to have been landed by a "Fed"
team.
Coach Hooper has had charge of
three Hopkins nines. He coached
the last year's squad, and in 1912
he coached the first baseball team
officially recognized as representing the University.

Through the action of the Board
of Collegiate Studies in changing
its policy toward hazing, the Student Council has been given • the
authority to proceed with its plans
in dealing with interclass rivalry.
The Board and Council have had
several joint meetings for a discussion of the topic, and because of
the arbitrariness and the absence
of allowance for extraordinary circumstances in the faculty's hazing
rule, it was decided to repeal it.
The rule, as stated in the front of
the course record book, is: "A student shall be liable to immediate
dismissal who shall, in any way, be
an actor or a participant in hazing
or interfering with class banquets,
or shall engage, in the gymnasium
or in any of the University buildings, in any form of hazing."
The inability to enforce this rule,
as evinced in recent occurrences,
coupled with its doubtful fairness
and the fact that the Student Council could undertake no revision of
hazing while it existed, argued for
its repeal from the regulations. The
repeal, however, does not indicate
that the faculty will tolerate hazing. The Board has simply adopted
a new policy which is explained in
the following letter:
MR. H. E. CORNER,
Chairman Student Council.
MY DEAR MR. CORNER:
I am instructed, as secretary pro
ternpore of the Board of the College Studies, to inform you that the
recommendations of the joint meeting of the Committee of the Faculty and the Student Council have
been adopted by the Board. These
recommendations, you will remember, included the appointment by
the Board of a standing committee
on student affairs and the general
policy of naming no specific penalty
for breaches of good order; but
should any occur, of dealing with
each case on its merits.
Yours very truly,
JOHN C. FRENCH.
February 27, 1914.
The collegiate Board also granted
the request of the Student Council
to have a printed form in all examination books in which the student could write his pledge.
Progress has been made in both
of the two plans considered by the
Council for the changes in hazing.
President Thompson, of the freshman class, has appointed a committees which will frame "freshman
regulations."

McCoy Hall will be the scene
next Friday night of one of the
most interesting of our annual affairs. The junior and senior classes
will, through their representatives,
contest for the Adams Trophy, and
selected speakers from the sophomore class will try for the Adams
Medal. Members of three classes
will, therefore, be interested in the
event, and freshmen will doubtless
also be inquisitive enough to wish
to attend. Cards of admission can
be obtained from any one of the
Invitation Committee. There will
probably be some music by the
Glee or Instrumental Club to fill
out the program.
The oratorical contest will come
first on the program. Tingley,
Webb-Peploe and Cohn will be the
contestants. The judges of this
contest and also of the debate have
not been finally decided upon. In
the debate, the juniors will fire the
first shot in favor of abandonment
of the Monroe Doctrine. They will
speak in the following order: Bartlett, Eiseman and Weech. The
seniors will uphold the negative
and speak as follows: Lauchheimer,
Weber and White. Each side will
have two twelve-minute speeches
of argument and then ten minutes
of rebuttal. The winning side will
contribute to the collection of tablets at the south end of the corridor on the second floor of McCoy
Hall.
It is difficult to prophesy which
side will be victorious. For a number of years the junior class has
come off victorious. The present
senior class has seen three successive junior victories, including its
own, last year. If the seniors
should win this year, they will be
the first in a long time to have won
both of the debates. This year's
junior team has a majority of experienced speakers, while only one
of the seniors has been heard here
before.
Within a week or so after this
debate, the try-outs will be held for
the more important intercollegiate
contest which will be held on the
night of Saturday, April 18. Hopkins will have two teams, one on
each side, the question being the
same as that argued by the upper
classes.. Places °I_ the intercollegiate teams are open not only to
members of the two class teams,
but to other students as well. The
Hopkins negative team will go to
Charlottesville, Va. and there meet
the University of'
North Carolina,

(Continued on page 8, col. 3)

(Continued on page 8, col. 3)

The track team made a glorious
finish for their indoor season by
winning first honors last Saturday
night in the annual Georgetown
games, with a score of 22 points.
Yale men were second, with 18
points, and Georgetown came third
with fo. Hopkins also won 14
points which did not count in the
team score-6 in novice events and
8 in S. A. A. Championships—making a total of 36 points won by
the Black and Blue.
The meet opened with the 50yard dashes, in which Hopkins
failed to show up strongly, Binford, with third place in the novice
event, being the only man to place.
The heavy scoring was begun by
the field men, when Connolly won
first place in both Ihe open and
championship high jump, and Sturgis took second in the two shotputs. Connolly's jump in the .open
event was 5 feet i i inches, and in
the championships 5 feet To inches.
In the other field event Hopkins
also won honors, Tappan winning
the pole-vault by the height of
feet fo inches, including his handicap. This gave the Black and Blue
13 in the point score.
Melamet and Wells added eight
points to this by capturing the first
two places in the open 44o-yard
dash. Melamet ran a beautiful
race, and Wells finished close to
him. The time was 523's seconds.
Still another point was brought
in to make up the total of 22, by
Lloyd, who got third place in the
open 880-yard run. Hopkins entered six men in this race, but
Lloyd was the only man able to
break through the crowd and place.
Catlin made a good fight in both
the half and the mile, but was unable to overcome the large handicaps. Binford also won the novice
600-yard dash, securing first in
both his heat and the finals.
It was the last meet of the very
successful indoor season. The first
two meets were "walk-aways"; in
the Armory meet all three of the
relay teams were victorious; the
following week the first relay men
defeated Lehigh by a large margin, and this final triumph at
'the Georgetown games, with the
others, points to bright prospects
for the coming and more important
outdoor schedule. The men will
have a few weeks rest now before
beginning of the hard training for
the first outdoor contest, which will
be a dual meet with Navy on the
Friday after Easter.

Of special interest, however, was
the report of the Homewood Committee concerning the progi-ess of
the building operations, and the
discussion of the "cordial manner
in which the announcement of the
election of Dr. Goodnow as president had been received."
It was also reported that a cablegram had been sent Dr. Goodnow
after the Commemoration Day exercises, telling him that his election
had been greeted "with much praise
by officers, faculty and citizens."
As yet, no cables have been received from Dr. Goodnow since his
acceptance, and the members of the
Board are eagerly awaiting the arrival of a letter.
Several small appropriations were
made at the meeting.

SOPH BANQUET GREAT SUCCESS

SUMMER WORK IS COMPULSORY

Clever Speech-making, Two Poetic Parodies, and Five Freshman Guests,
Factors in '16 Gayety.

All Technical Students Will Be Required
to Spend at Least One Vacation
at Some Practical Job.

In each of the three departments
essential to the suCcess of a sophomore banquet—food, speeches, and
unwilling freshmen guests—the 'r6
dinner at the Rennert Wednesday
was excellently provided for.
Five freshmen—all gathered in
through the untiring efforts of
Woodward and his co-workers—
furnished amusement for awhile
with song and dance, after which
they were photographed by Vickers,
who also took flashlights of the
diners. Masters Boyce, Pitt, Kohn,
Dawson and Emanuel Gichner, the
latter of Homewood fame, were the
unfortunate freshmen. Gichner was
called upon for a speech, and although not in his usual voice,
managed to say some things complimentary to 1916 in general, and
with little more ado the five unfortunates were forcibly ejected
from the hall.
Myron Bagley was an accomplished toastmaster. The set speeches
were:
"The Class," Henry G. Rutledge.
"The University," Hiram W.
Woodward.
"Frau Sorge," Thomas Tingley.
"Ma Greene," Dorsey Richardson.
"To liven in delyt was ever his wone
For he was epicurus owne sone."
"The Northern Police Station,"
Samuel L. Leitheiser.
Of these, the distinct hit of the
evening was Tingley's parody of
"Gunga Din," 'under the head of
"Frau Sorge." In introducing him,
Toastinaster Bagley stated that
"Sorge" was Hindustani for "Griffin," and it was in this meaning that
Tingley treated the word.
Another poetical effort was Richardson's "The Legende of a Goode
Woman," in the language and metre
used by Chaucer. Rutledge, Woodward and Leitheiser stuck to prose,
and gave amusing and telling talks.
Of the informal speakers, John
Knipp drew forth great applause
with what was described by one
auditor as a "delightfully risque"
discourse on "One Day," a play
much admired by many in the class.
McCormick, though unprepared,
delivered a very clever oration on
the Homewood affair. Penniman,
Primrose and "Rube" Vickers spoke
in response to toasts, and Walter
Wood proposed a clever class toast
in verse, which was received with
enthusiasm.
The fact that some freshmen
were brought in made everyone feel
that the class had kept the upper
hand in the recent troubles, but
their presence was not allowed to
disturb the orderly conduct of the
banquet. The menu card was illustrated with a flashlight photograph of the hazing party of November 10 last, taken before the
Northern Police Station.

Dr. Whitehead, professor of electrical engineering, announced before the Engineering Society at its
meeting Monday that one summer
of practical work along some technical line would be required of all
engineering students before the
University will confer a degree
upon them.
The idea, original with the Hopkins technical department, has obvious advantages. The work is to
be of such a character as to meet
with the approval of the .professors,
and each student will be required
to make a, report on the work he
has done. Dr. Whitehead said that
the faculty would assist in finding
the employment, but advised that
anyone with "pull" should endeavor
to locate himself.
The announcement of the policy
had not before been officially made
to students in the engineering
courses, although many knew that
such a plan had been decided upon.
Dr. Whitehead was the speaker before the Engineering Society Monday, and took that occasion to announce the faculty's rule.
Dr. Whitehead then spoke on
"The New Nitrogen-Filled Tungsten Lamps." These new incandescent lamps have an efficiency of 20
per cent, as compared with the 2
per cent, of the ordinary carbon
lamps, and the 10 per cent. of the
tungsten lamps now in use. They
are manufactured by the General
Electric Company, and are soon to
be put on the market.
Two of the lamps were shown
and their brilliancy nearly dazzled
the audience, as they were of about
1,500 candle-power each.
Before lighting the lamps, Dr.
Whitehead gave a brief account of
the discoveries which led to their
production. He also gave a detailed description of their construction, and explained that the reason
lighting apparatus was so inefficient
as compared with other electric apparatus was because so much.energy
was lost in heat.
After the meeting, the speaker
said that there was a great field for
work in lighting problems and that
he thought that "cold light" would
ultimately be produced.
Dr. Whitehead's talk was much
enjoyed by the members, who gave
him a vote of thanks at the close
of his address.

BALTIMORE, MD., MAR. 9, 1914.

The Musical Clubs.

Conversations heard on the mornings after concerts given by the
combined Musical Clubs indicate
•that there is something radically
wrong either with the management
of the Clubs or with the spirit of
their members. The last two concerts have been described as "rotten" and "frosts."
' According to reports, the Clubs
"held together" during the season
covering the Eastern Shore trip
and the McCoy Hall entertainment,
but there has been a decided lack
of interest shown by the members
since. The concert in Catonsville
was poorly given because of the
absence of a great many of the
singers and players through reasons unexplained, and concerts at
local churches have been affected
the same way. A poor showing
has been made because of wholesale absence.
The managers of the Clubs say
the members are not showing the
proper spirit, and the members say
the management is at fault because
it has-arranged too many concerts
after the McCoy Hall one. It so
happens that a great many of the
members are now interested in
other activities and find it difficult
to "keep up this singing and playing all year."
The situation is indeed an unwholesome one. Those members
who have stuck loyally to the finish
deserve thanks, but it must be
remembered that the Clubs are
not representing Hopkins as they
should. One more concert is to be
given—that at Walbrook. All the
men who gang or played on the trip
and at McCoy Hall entertainments
should be on hand that night and
do their best. It is not a question

of their opinion as to the fault of
the management. They owe their
service to the Clubs and .to the University. When the concerts are a
failure, the University's traditions
suffer.

Prof. Alfred Noyes.

Alfred Noyes, considered by many
the foremost of living British poets,
has been offered a professorship at
Princeton and will probably accept.
Princeton wants him to give "second term" lectures on English literature.
Mr. Noyes undoubtedly deserves
fame as a writer of lyric verse; but
some of his opinions, and these will
be the basis of his work at Princeto.i, may be challenged. In Baltimore, in Boston, and no doubt in
many other cities during his present
tour of America, he has said in
newspaper interviews that Emerson
was a greater poet than Poe. The
question suggests itself: "Is Mr.
Noyes an accurate judge of poetry ?"
Emerson showed little, if any,
originality in verse. Poe, in that
respect, has been declared a genius.
In comparing the poetry of the two,
Professor Richardson's sentence:

The Student Council.

The repeal of the faculty's absolute prohibition of hazing has been
accomplished by the Student Council in several joint meetings with
the faculty. From now on such
matters of hazing that deserve to
be dealt with in a corrective manner
will come before the Council, and
the faculty will act upon its recommendations. The old rule that any
form of hazing is to be punished
with dismissal has been revoked,
and future cases will be dealt with
on their merits.
This work of the Student Council should not go by unappreciated,
for it is another step toward selfgovernment. The faculty has reposed confidence and authority in
the body, and if it is to be successful, all of the students will have to
show a like amount of respect and
confidence. The Student Council
can be made a great factor in student life, but it can hope for no
power until the students recognize
it as the logical tribunal for the
settlement of student problems.

Dr. Franz Oppenheimer, professor of political economy at the University of Berlin, will deliver two
lectures before the Economic Seminary, March 9 and ro, on "The
•
Theory of Wages."
Dr. Oppenheimer is one of the
group of brilliant young economists
whose scientific activity and stimulating influence is doing much to
maintain the traditional eminence
of Germany, and of the University
of Berlin in particular, in the domain of economic science. In addition to being an authority on the
subject of currency and wages, Dr.
Oppenheimer is at present engaged
on the theory of co-operative farming. His ideas are being given
practical tests in various parts of
Europe and in the Holy Land. It
was chiefly for the purpose of describing the results of this latter
work that he was invited to this
country.
The Hopkins economics faculty,
on learning of the arrival of Dr.
Oppenheimer in America, immediately began negotiations to have
him speak here.

THE NEWS—LETTER, MARCH 9, 1914.

FOUR WAR CAMPS FOR STUDENTS
Five Weeks' Vacation Offered by U. S.
Government at Nominal Expense.
Idea to Improve the Army.

College students and graduates
between the ages of eighteen and
thirty, who are seeking something
to do during the summer, will undoubtedly be interested that the
War Department, following the
successful plan of last summer, will
establish this summer four military
instruction camps for a period of
five weeks.
The idea back of these camps is
to build up a reserve force from
which officers of volunteers can be
drawn in time of war, and to open
to the young men of America .an
opportunity to enjoy a pleasant
summer outing—all at a very moderate cost.
One camp will be at Burlington,
Vt., from July 6 to August 7, inclusive; another at Monterey, Cal.,
from June 26 to July 31, inclusive,
and another in the mountain and
spring region of Virginia, or a little
to the south, and the fourth on the
eastern shore of Lake Michigan,
the exact location and the dates for
the two latter encampments to be
announced later.
In the camps, training will be
given in infantry drill and maneuvers, and instruction will be
given in artillery, cavalry, engineer
and signal corps work, in their relation to infantry attack, defense,
etc. The War Department details
troops of all branches to these
camps for the better instruction of
men. The total cost to the "student soldiers" will be $22.50, $17.50 for subsistence, and $5 for uniform.
These camps have been commended by the presidents of America's leading colleges and by other
men of national reputation. President Woodrow Wilson says:
"I believe the students attending
these college camps will derive not
only a great deal of physical benefit from the healthful open-air life,
but also that they will benefit from
the discipline, habits of regularity
and the knowledge of personal and
camp sanitation which the experience in camp will give them."
Application blanks for enrollment
in the camps of 1914 can be obtained from Capt. R. 0. Van Horn,
general staff, United States Army;
office cif chief of staff, War Department Building, Washington, D. C.
Dr. R. V. D. Magoffir.i has ample
literature for distribution.
St. John's Baseball Practice Begun.

Candidates for the St. Jahn's
baseball team are practicing in the
gymnasium, and with two to eight
aspirants for the various positions,
there is an unusual spirit of competition. "Lefty" Wilson, for several
years a member of St. John's teams,
is coach. Mellon, Gerring and J.
Matthews have been lost by graduation. Noble, H. B. Matthews,
Clarke, Heise, Thompson, Claude
and Moisan are regulars remaining.

The appearance of Levering Hall,
on Friday, Saturday and Sunday,
would have made a stranger think
that he was at a co-ed school.
Under the auspices of the Student
Volunteer - Movement, there were
being held a series of meetings to
which delegates came from all parts
of the State: Hopkins, Goucher,
Hood (Frederick), Washington,
Western Maryland, University of
Maryland, St. John's, and Physicians and Surgeons colleges being
represented. The presence of about
20 girls from Frederick and 30 or
more from Goucher made Levering
Hall a busy place.
The opening meeting was held
Friday evening. Three were held
Saturday, and on Sunday afternoon
the Conference met at Goucher College Chapel. The final meeting was
held here on Sunday night. Many
prominent speakers addressed the
meetings, including Dr. Hogue, of
Baltimore; Dr. Jeffries, of Shanghai; Mr. Connor, of South America; Miss Duffield, secretary of the
Volunteer Movement, and other
representatives from non-Christian
countries. The meetings were under
the direction of Mr. Leiper, one of
the secretaries of the Volunteer
Movement. Many of those who attended these meetings expressed
the interest in missions which they
had aroused, and several declared
their intention of volunteering.

JOHNS HOPKINS UNIVERSITY
VOL. XVIII, NO. 19.

BALTIMORE, MD., MARCH 9, 1914.

PRICE, FIVE CENTS

HOOPER SIGNS WITH THE "FEDS"

HAZING IS PUT ON A NEW BASIS

INTERCLASS CONTEST ON FRIDAY HOPKINS TRACK MEN VICTORIOUS

Baseball Coach Signs One-Year Contract
With Pittsburgh —Will Not Interfere With His Work Here.

Faculty Revises Rules and Vests Student
Council With Regulating Power.
Novel Contest Planned.

Juniors and Seniors to Debate on Monroe
Doctrine—Sophomore Oratorical
Contest at Same Time.

Win Meet and Handsome Cup in Annual
Georgetown Games—Connolly
Is S. A.A. Champion.

"Eddie" Hooper, coach of the
'Varsity baseball team, has signed
a one-year contract with the Pittsburgh team of the Federal League.
The position, however, will interfere in no manner with his connection with Hopkins, for he will
not join the Smoky City team until
he has whipped the Hopkins nine
into shape and piloted it through
its schedule.
Coach Hooper was formerly a
member of the York (Tri-State)
team and last season was one of
its most sensational fielders. He
was a player on the Baltimore
Orioles before going to York. While
on the local team, however, he had
continuous trouble with his arm,
which interfered with batting, and
he was forced to retire to a league
where he would not be required
to play so strenuously.
Nearly a month ago friends of
Coach Hooper learned that the
"Feds" were flirting with him.
First came the rumor that the
Indianapolis team wanted him, but
later it developed that Pittsburgh
had taken a fancy to his excellent
record as a fielder for York. The
offer came to Coach Hooper, but
he said nothing about it to his Hopkins charges. He considered the
•
`jump"
for some time, and finally
decided to sign the Pittsburgh contract.
It will not be necessary, however,
for him to leave the Hopkins team
until its season is closed. Even
while a member of the York team
he went through nearly the whole
Hopkins season before reporting
to his own team, and as the Teds"
will not organize until late in the
year, he will possibly be able to be
with the 'Varsity the entire season
this year before leaving.
The contract signed with Pittsburgh calls for one year's service,
and the salary is a great deal more
attractive than that of York. Coach
Hooper will be playing in company
with some of the big stars of the
Americah national game, and if current reports are to be believed, he
will face the pitching of "Christy"
Mathewson, the Giant, who is said
- to have been landed by a "Fed"
team.
Coach Hooper has had charge of
three Hopkins nines. He coached
the last year's squad, and in 1912
he coached the first baseball team
officially recognized as representing the University.

Through the action of the Board
of Collegiate Studies in changing
its policy toward hazing, the Student Council has been given • the
authority to proceed with its plans
in dealing with interclass rivalry.
The Board and Council have had
several joint meetings for a discussion of the topic, and because of
the arbitrariness and the absence
of allowance for extraordinary circumstances in the faculty's hazing
rule, it was decided to repeal it.
The rule, as stated in the front of
the course record book, is: "A student shall be liable to immediate
dismissal who shall, in any way, be
an actor or a participant in hazing
or interfering with class banquets,
or shall engage, in the gymnasium
or in any of the University buildings, in any form of hazing."
The inability to enforce this rule,
as evinced in recent occurrences,
coupled with its doubtful fairness
and the fact that the Student Council could undertake no revision of
hazing while it existed, argued for
its repeal from the regulations. The
repeal, however, does not indicate
that the faculty will tolerate hazing. The Board has simply adopted
a new policy which is explained in
the following letter:
MR. H. E. CORNER,
Chairman Student Council.
MY DEAR MR. CORNER:
I am instructed, as secretary pro
ternpore of the Board of the College Studies, to inform you that the
recommendations of the joint meeting of the Committee of the Faculty and the Student Council have
been adopted by the Board. These
recommendations, you will remember, included the appointment by
the Board of a standing committee
on student affairs and the general
policy of naming no specific penalty
for breaches of good order; but
should any occur, of dealing with
each case on its merits.
Yours very truly,
JOHN C. FRENCH.
February 27, 1914.
The collegiate Board also granted
the request of the Student Council
to have a printed form in all examination books in which the student could write his pledge.
Progress has been made in both
of the two plans considered by the
Council for the changes in hazing.
President Thompson, of the freshman class, has appointed a committees which will frame "freshman
regulations."

McCoy Hall will be the scene
next Friday night of one of the
most interesting of our annual affairs. The junior and senior classes
will, through their representatives,
contest for the Adams Trophy, and
selected speakers from the sophomore class will try for the Adams
Medal. Members of three classes
will, therefore, be interested in the
event, and freshmen will doubtless
also be inquisitive enough to wish
to attend. Cards of admission can
be obtained from any one of the
Invitation Committee. There will
probably be some music by the
Glee or Instrumental Club to fill
out the program.
The oratorical contest will come
first on the program. Tingley,
Webb-Peploe and Cohn will be the
contestants. The judges of this
contest and also of the debate have
not been finally decided upon. In
the debate, the juniors will fire the
first shot in favor of abandonment
of the Monroe Doctrine. They will
speak in the following order: Bartlett, Eiseman and Weech. The
seniors will uphold the negative
and speak as follows: Lauchheimer,
Weber and White. Each side will
have two twelve-minute speeches
of argument and then ten minutes
of rebuttal. The winning side will
contribute to the collection of tablets at the south end of the corridor on the second floor of McCoy
Hall.
It is difficult to prophesy which
side will be victorious. For a number of years the junior class has
come off victorious. The present
senior class has seen three successive junior victories, including its
own, last year. If the seniors
should win this year, they will be
the first in a long time to have won
both of the debates. This year's
junior team has a majority of experienced speakers, while only one
of the seniors has been heard here
before.
Within a week or so after this
debate, the try-outs will be held for
the more important intercollegiate
contest which will be held on the
night of Saturday, April 18. Hopkins will have two teams, one on
each side, the question being the
same as that argued by the upper
classes.. Places °I_ the intercollegiate teams are open not only to
members of the two class teams,
but to other students as well. The
Hopkins negative team will go to
Charlottesville, Va. and there meet
the University of'
North Carolina,

(Continued on page 8, col. 3)

(Continued on page 8, col. 3)

The track team made a glorious
finish for their indoor season by
winning first honors last Saturday
night in the annual Georgetown
games, with a score of 22 points.
Yale men were second, with 18
points, and Georgetown came third
with fo. Hopkins also won 14
points which did not count in the
team score-6 in novice events and
8 in S. A. A. Championships—making a total of 36 points won by
the Black and Blue.
The meet opened with the 50yard dashes, in which Hopkins
failed to show up strongly, Binford, with third place in the novice
event, being the only man to place.
The heavy scoring was begun by
the field men, when Connolly won
first place in both Ihe open and
championship high jump, and Sturgis took second in the two shotputs. Connolly's jump in the .open
event was 5 feet i i inches, and in
the championships 5 feet To inches.
In the other field event Hopkins
also won honors, Tappan winning
the pole-vault by the height of
feet fo inches, including his handicap. This gave the Black and Blue
13 in the point score.
Melamet and Wells added eight
points to this by capturing the first
two places in the open 44o-yard
dash. Melamet ran a beautiful
race, and Wells finished close to
him. The time was 523's seconds.
Still another point was brought
in to make up the total of 22, by
Lloyd, who got third place in the
open 880-yard run. Hopkins entered six men in this race, but
Lloyd was the only man able to
break through the crowd and place.
Catlin made a good fight in both
the half and the mile, but was unable to overcome the large handicaps. Binford also won the novice
600-yard dash, securing first in
both his heat and the finals.
It was the last meet of the very
successful indoor season. The first
two meets were "walk-aways"; in
the Armory meet all three of the
relay teams were victorious; the
following week the first relay men
defeated Lehigh by a large margin, and this final triumph at
'the Georgetown games, with the
others, points to bright prospects
for the coming and more important
outdoor schedule. The men will
have a few weeks rest now before
beginning of the hard training for
the first outdoor contest, which will
be a dual meet with Navy on the
Friday after Easter.

SOPH BANQUET GREAT SUCCESS

In each of the three departments
essential to the suCcess of a sophomore banquet—food, speeches, and
unwilling freshmen guests—the 'r6
dinner at the Rennert Wednesday
was excellently provided for.
Five freshmen—all gathered in
through the untiring efforts of
Woodward and his co-workers—
furnished amusement for awhile
with song and dance, after which
they were photographed by Vickers,
who also took flashlights of the
diners. Masters Boyce, Pitt, Kohn,
Dawson and Emanuel Gichner, the
latter of Homewood fame, were the
unfortunate freshmen. Gichner was
called upon for a speech, and although not in his usual voice,
managed to say some things complimentary to 1916 in general, and
with little more ado the five unfortunates were forcibly ejected
from the hall.
Myron Bagley was an accomplished toastmaster. The set speeches
were:
"The Class," Henry G. Rutledge.
"The University," Hiram W.
Woodward.
"Frau Sorge," Thomas Tingley.
"Ma Greene," Dorsey Richardson.
"To liven in delyt was ever his wone
For he was epicurus owne sone."
"The Northern Police Station,"
Samuel L. Leitheiser.
Of these, the distinct hit of the
evening was Tingley's parody of
"Gunga Din," 'under the head of
"Frau Sorge." In introducing him,
Toastinaster Bagley stated that
"Sorge" was Hindustani for "Griffin," and it was in this meaning that
Tingley treated the word.
Another poetical effort was Richardson's "The Legende of a Goode
Woman," in the language and metre
used by Chaucer. Rutledge, Woodward and Leitheiser stuck to prose,
and gave amusing and telling talks.
Of the informal speakers, John
Knipp drew forth great applause
with what was described by one
auditor as a "delightfully risque"
discourse on "One Day," a play
much admired by many in the class.
McCormick, though unprepared,
delivered a very clever oration on
the Homewood affair. Penniman,
Primrose and "Rube" Vickers spoke
in response to toasts, and Walter
Wood proposed a clever class toast
in verse, which was received with
enthusiasm.
The fact that some freshmen
were brought in made everyone feel
that the class had kept the upper
hand in the recent troubles, but
their presence was not allowed to
disturb the orderly conduct of the
banquet. The menu card was illustrated with a flashlight photograph of the hazing party of November 10 last, taken before the
Northern Police Station.

Dr. Whitehead, professor of electrical engineering, announced before the Engineering Society at its
meeting Monday that one summer
of practical work along some technical line would be required of all
engineering students before the
University will confer a degree
upon them.
The idea, original with the Hopkins technical department, has obvious advantages. The work is to
be of such a character as to meet
with the approval of the .professors,
and each student will be required
to make a, report on the work he
has done. Dr. Whitehead said that
the faculty would assist in finding
the employment, but advised that
anyone with "pull" should endeavor
to locate himself.
The announcement of the policy
had not before been officially made
to students in the engineering
courses, although many knew that
such a plan had been decided upon.
Dr. Whitehead was the speaker before the Engineering Society Monday, and took that occasion to announce the faculty's rule.
Dr. Whitehead then spoke on
"The New Nitrogen-Filled Tungsten Lamps." These new incandescent lamps have an efficiency of 20
per cent, as compared with the 2
per cent, of the ordinary carbon
lamps, and the 10 per cent. of the
tungsten lamps now in use. They
are manufactured by the General
Electric Company, and are soon to
be put on the market.
Two of the lamps were shown
and their brilliancy nearly dazzled
the audience, as they were of about
1,500 candle-power each.
Before lighting the lamps, Dr.
Whitehead gave a brief account of
the discoveries which led to their
production. He also gave a detailed description of their construction, and explained that the reason
lighting apparatus was so inefficient
as compared with other electric apparatus was because so much.energy
was lost in heat.
After the meeting, the speaker
said that there was a great field for
work in lighting problems and that
he thought that "cold light" would
ultimately be produced.
Dr. Whitehead's talk was much

BALTIMORE, MD., MAR. 9, 1914.

The Musical Clubs.

Conversations heard on the mornings after concerts given by the
combined Musical Clubs indicate
•that there is something radically
wrong either with the management
of the Clubs or with the spirit of
their members. The last two concerts have been described as "rotten" and "frosts."
' According to reports, the Clubs
"held together" during the season
covering the Eastern Shore trip
and the McCoy Hall entertainment,
but there has been a decided lack
of interest shown by the members
since. The concert in Catonsville
was poorly given because of the
absence of a great many of the
singers and players through reasons unexplained, and concerts at
local churches have been affected
the same way. A poor showing
has been made because of wholesale absence.
The managers of the Clubs say
the members are not showing the
proper spirit, and the members say
the management is at fault because
it has-arranged too many concerts
after the McCoy Hall one. It so
happens that a great many of the
members are now interested in
other activities and find it difficult
to "keep up this singing and playing all year."
The situation is indeed an unwholesome one. Those members
who have stuck loyally to the finish
deserve thanks, but it must be
remembered that the Clubs are
not representing Hopkins as they
should. One more concert is to be
given—that at Walbrook. All the
men who gang or played on the trip
and at McCoy Hall entertainments
should be on hand that night and
do their best. It is not a question

of their opinion as to the fault of
the management. They owe their
service to the Clubs and .to the University. When the concerts are a
failure, the University's traditions
suffer.

Prof. Alfred Noyes.

Alfred Noyes, considered by many
the foremost of living British poets,
has been offered a professorship at
Princeton and will probably accept.
Princeton wants him to give "second term" lectures on English literature.
Mr. Noyes undoubtedly deserves
fame as a writer of lyric verse; but
some of his opinions, and these will
be the basis of his work at Princeto.i, may be challenged. In Baltimore, in Boston, and no doubt in
many other cities during his present
tour of America, he has said in
newspaper interviews that Emerson
was a greater poet than Poe. The
question suggests itself: "Is Mr.
Noyes an accurate judge of poetry ?"
Emerson showed little, if any,
originality in verse. Poe, in that
respect, has been declared a genius.
In comparing the poetry of the two,
Professor Richardson's sentence:
"If we mean ethics we men one
thing; if art, another," is strikingly
appropriate. Emerson, we agree,
was superior as a philosopher, but
Poe was the artist. Who can select
from among all of Emersoh's poems
any two that can compare with
"The Bells" and "To Helen"?

The Student Council.

The repeal of the faculty's absolute prohibition of hazing has been
accomplished by the Student Council in several joint meetings with
the faculty. From now on such
matters of hazing that deserve to
be dealt with in a corrective manner
will come before the Council, and
the faculty will act upon its recommendations. The old rule that any
form of hazing is to be punished
with dismissal has been revoked,
and future cases will be dealt with
on their merits.
This work of the Student Council should not go by unappreciated,
for it is another step toward selfgovernment. The faculty has reposed confidence and authority in
the body, and if it is to be successful, all of the students will have to
show a like amount of respect and
confidence. The Student Council
can be made a great factor in student life, but it can hope for no
power until the students recognize
it as the logical tribunal for the
settlement of student problems.

Dr. Franz Oppenheimer, professor of political economy at the University of Berlin, will deliver two
lectures before the Economic Seminary, March 9 and ro, on "The
•
Theory of Wages."
Dr. Oppenheimer is one of the
group of brilliant young economists
whose scientific activity and stimulating influence is doing much to
maintain the traditional eminence
of Germany, and of the University
of Berlin in particular, in the domain of economic science. In addition to being an authority on the
subject of currency and wages, Dr.
Oppenheimer is at present engaged
on the theory of co-operative farming. His ideas are being given
practical tests in various parts of
Europe and in the Holy Land. It
was chiefly for the purpose of describing the results of this latter
work that he was invited to this
country.
The Hopkins economics faculty,
on learning of the arrival of Dr.
Oppenheimer in America, immediately began negotiations to have
him speak here.

THE NEWS—LETTER, MARCH 9, 1914.

FOUR WAR CAMPS FOR STUDENTS
Five Weeks' Vacation Offered by U. S.
Government at Nominal Expense.
Idea to Improve the Army.

College students and graduates
between the ages of eighteen and
thirty, who are seeking something
to do during the summer, will undoubtedly be interested that the
War Department, following the
successful plan of last summer, will
establish this summer four military
instruction camps for a period of
five weeks.
The idea back of these camps is
to build up a reserve force from
which officers of volunteers can be
drawn in time of war, and to open
to the young men of America .an
opportunity to enjoy a pleasant
summer outing—all at a very moderate cost.
One camp will be at Burlington,
Vt., from July 6 to August 7, inclusive; another at Monterey, Cal.,
from June 26 to July 31, inclusive,
and another in the mountain and
spring region of Virginia, or a little
to the south, and the fourth on the
eastern shore of Lake Michigan,
the exact location and the dates for
the two latter encampments to be
announced later.
In the camps, training will be
given in infantry drill and maneuvers, and instruction will be
given in artillery, cavalry, engineer
and signal corps work, in their relation to infantry attack, defense,
etc. The War Department details
troops of all branches to these
camps for the better instruction of
men. The total cost to the "student soldiers" will be $22.50, $17.50 for subsistence, and $5 for uniform.
These camps have been commended by the presidents of America's leading colleges and by other
men of national reputation. President Woodrow Wilson says:
"I believe the students attending
these college camps will derive not
only a great deal of physical benefit from the healthful open-air life,
but also that they will benefit from
the discipline, habits of regularity
and the knowledge of personal and
camp sanitation which the experience in camp will give them."
Application blanks for enrollment
in the camps of 1914 can be obtained from Capt. R. 0. Van Horn,
general staff, United States Army;
office cif chief of staff, War Department Building, Washington, D. C.
Dr. R. V. D. Magoffir.i has ample
literature for distribution.

Candidates for the St. Jahn's

aspirants for the various positions,
there is an unusual spirit of competition. "Lefty" Wilson, for several
years a member of St. John's teams,
is coach. Mellon, Gerring and J.
Matthews have been lost by graduation. Noble, H. B. Matthews,
Clarke, Heise, Thompson, Claude
and Moisan are regulars remaining.

The appearance of Levering Hall,
on Friday, Saturday and Sunday,
would have made a stranger think
that he was at a co-ed school.
Under the auspices of the Student
Volunteer - Movement, there were
being held a series of meetings to
which delegates came from all parts
of the State: Hopkins, Goucher,
Hood (Frederick), Washington,
Western Maryland, University of
Maryland, St. John's, and Physicians and Surgeons colleges being
represented. The presence of about
20 girls from Frederick and 30 or
more from Goucher made Levering
Hall a busy place.
The opening meeting was held
Friday evening. Three were held
Saturday, and on Sunday afternoon
the Conference met at Goucher College Chapel. The final meeting was
held here on Sunday night. Many
prominent speakers addressed the
meetings, including Dr. Hogue, of
Baltimore; Dr. Jeffries, of Shanghai; Mr. Connor, of South America; Miss Duffield, secretary of the
Volunteer Movement, and other
representatives from non-Christian
countries. The meetings were under
the direction of Mr. Leiper, one of
the secretaries of the Volunteer
Movement. Many of those who attended these meetings expressed
the interest in missions which they
had aroused, and several declared
their intention of volunteering.
